newsitem.title: EGYPT: Minister says committed to stable Egypt pound/dlr.
newsitem.headline: Minister says committed to stable Egypt pound/dlr.

text.p: An Egyptian minister on Monday dismissed the Egyptian pound's recent appreciation against the dollar as a temporary aberration and predicted the rate would stabilise.
"We don't intend to let it (the pound) appreciate. It's going to stay stable," said Youssef Boutros-Ghali, minister of state for economic affairs in the prime minister's office.

Commenting on last week's slight appreciation of the pound, on the back of heavy foreign currency inflows into Egypt's capital markets, Boutros-Ghali told Reuters "There are bound to be hiccups from time to time."

This month, the pound has gained about half a piastre against the dollar, less than one quarter of a percent. That change is small by international standards but significant to those in the Cairo market, where pound-dollar rates have hardly changed for years. Bankers speculated the central bank bought surplus dollars, adding to Egypt's large foreign reserves. The process is opaque because secretive public-sector banks usually act as intermediaries between the central bank and the market, but foreign reserves were last reported at about $19 billion, enough for more than 14 months of imports. Asked if the central bank was buying, Boutros-Ghali said "I suspect so." He said he had not seen new foreign reserves data. Boutros-Ghali said M2 money supply grew in the period July-December 1996 at the equivalent of 11.2 percent a year, suggesting that monetary authorities were able to neutralise the effect of the large foreign currency inflows during that period.
In the previous half-year, M2 money supply had grown at the equivalent of 11.8 percent a year.
